Posts.Content: May 3, 2009 02:58PM MI_Runner wrote: Hi all.  I'll be having a bilateral mastectomy (1 affected, 1 prophylactic) sometime this month.  My surgery has not be scheduled yet, pending a meeting with a second surgeon bright and early tomorrow morning.   I'm getting scared about surgery and recovery.  What are you all doing to prepare? I feel a bit like I don't know what to expect or what I need to do before the surgery to be ready.  I'll take any advice you have to spare!
Posts.Title: May 2009 surgery lovinmomma dkhancock1948

Posts.Content: May 4, 2009 01:42PM - edited May 4, 2009 01:43PM by MI_Runner Checking back in.  I saw the second surgeon this morning, and he agreed that the bilateral mastectomy is a logical decision.  He actually said there's some scientfic evidence to suggest that lumpectomy + radiation is not as effective in younger women, and he supported my decision.  That helps me feel a little bit better, and also will hopefully help with getting insurance to pay for both.  If insurance won't cover the prophylactic, I'll have to wait.  The life of a poor graduate student...Anyway, the scheduleing coordinator was working on getting me worked in when I left, could be as early as this coming Monday (5/11).  The earlier the better, as far as I'm concerned.  I'm scared, but I'm ready to move past this.  Waiting and dreading surgery and chemo is just awful. Jayne in UK - it's nice to know others go through the same feelings. Mary - thanks for stopping by.  Good to hear that your surgery went well. Cherneski - hope you're feeling better today Candy - good luck tomorrow!  I hope everything goes swimmingly for you. Later all.  I have a final tomorrow.  Just finished my take home and got that turned in - all 20 single spaced, 10pt font pages of it.  One more day and I'm done with school for the semester. Oh, one other thing.  If all goes well I'll actually be flying at the end of the month for a professional conference.  Does anyone know where I get the compression sleeve?
Posts.Title: May 2009 surgery lovinmomma dkhancock1948

Posts.Content: May 8, 2009 09:32AM MI_Runner wrote: Jayne - we can be surgery buddies.  I hope yours goes well - no fair that you don't have to be there as early as me!  My doctor said I'll probably just be in the hospital one night.  Anne - we were diagnosed the same day, and your surgery is the day after mine.  I know what you mean by waiting for the other shoe to drop.  Alyad - thanks for dropping in.  It's goo dto hear that you're doing well.  One thing I'm wondering is what recovery will be like. I'm in very good shape because I was planning to race a lot this summer and run a marathon in the fall and I feel like that should help me in recovery, but I really feel like I don't know what to expect.  Does anyone know how soon we can expect to be able to move around the house, when I can walk my dog, etc?
Posts.Title: May 2009 surgery lovinmomma dkhancock1948

Posts.Content: May 6, 2009 08:16PM MI_Runner wrote: don23 - Losing my hair scares me more than losing The Girls, too!  I feel like without hair, I'm really going to look like a prepubescent boy.
Posts.Title: May 2009 surgery lovinmomma dkhancock1948

Posts.Content: May 6, 2009 04:58PM MI_Runner wrote: Me again - how is everyone doing?  We had a couple ladies with surgery this week - hopefully all went well and we'll hear from them soon. My surgery has been scheduled for Monday, 5/11.  Bright and early - I have to be there at 6 AM.  I'm scared, but it was actually a relief to have it scheduled.  Waiting has been so hard.
Posts.Title: May 2009 surgery lovinmomma dkhancock1948

Posts.Content: May 18, 2009 05:49PM - edited May 18, 2009 05:50PM by MI_Runner Follow-up with my surgeon today: Drains out (exactly 1 week) Pathology report was clean - lymph nodes clear, nothing in my left breast BRCA1/BRCA2 negative Unfortunately, HER2 was also negative, so I'm triple negative.... And, he cleared me to run when I feel up to it
Posts.Title: May 2009 surgery lovinmomma dkhancock1948

Posts.Content: May 3, 2009 06:28PM MI_Runner wrote: Cherneski, I don't think you need to appologize for being angry - we've all felt that way.  I got through phases, myself, of feeling very angry, sorry for myself, pragmatic and clinical, etc. Overall I feel like I'm handling all of this very well, but I'm angry to have to deal with it and I'm angry that I'm only 28 and have to make all these decisions I never thought I would have to make so early.  Impending surgery is SCARY, there's no way around it, and no one wants to do it. Meanwhile, I'm supposed to be working on a take home final (1st year PhD student...this should be fun) and keep finding myself on various bc sites trying to figure things out.  Sigh. Time to set the kitchen timer and get back to working in blocks.
Posts.Title: May 2009 surgery lovinmomma dkhancock1948

Posts.Content: May 15, 2009 03:37PM MI_Runner wrote: Hi everyone, Glad to hear surgery has gone well for those who went in this week, and good wishes to those going in the next few days. My bilateral mx. was Monday, no reconstruction (I'm doing delayed).  It went well, and the sentinel node biopsy was clear in the preliminary analysis. I was in the hospital until late Tuesday afternoon and have been home with mom and bf since then.  I'm doing well since arriving home.  In fact, the hospital sent a visiting nurse on Wednesday and today - when today's nurse arrived, she was shocked to learn I was the patient - that's good news!  My arms and chest are tight so I can't reach high shelves or anything like that.  I've been walking along with the dog, but haven't felt comfortable holding her leash yet. Mom leaves on Sunday so I'll have to start, bf can't do it all.  The most annoying problems I'm having now are itchiness under my tape and getting tired of sleeping on my back - these things will pass.  I have two drains that I've been emptying a couple times a day and the amount of fluid is decreasing.  My post-op appointment is Monday afternoon. Hope everyone's surgeries and recoveries go well!
Posts.Title: May 2009 surgery lovinmomma dkhancock1948

Posts.Content: MI_Runner wrote: Does anyone know how soon after surgery we can start taking NSAIDs again?  My period showed up today (almost a month late, btw) and I'd give just about anything for some Advil right about now.... My surgery was two weeks ago tomorrow. Dx 4/20/2009, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/1 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

thank you for giving me a choice seltzer wallycat

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2009 08:42PM - edited Jun 8, 2009 08:42PM by MI_Runner Kate - I had a bilateral mastectomy on 5/11(without reconstruction), had the drains out and got cleared to run by my surgeon on 5/18.  I started back with a run/walk plan just to be sure I didn't overdo it, even though I was very fit before surgery.  Now, 4 weeks later, I'm feeling almost back to my old self! Like LoriBaby and Alo, fatigue was the biggest thing.  I am just trying to pay close attention to how I feel and take a day off if I need it.

Posts.Content: MI_Runner wrote: Hi all, I had a bilateral mx on 5/11 and am attending a professional conference starting on 5/26.  I chose delayed reconstruction, so there's nothing there right now.  They gave me two foam prosthetics at the hosptial, but I feel like they give me Madonna boobs so I'm not a huge fan.  I haven't tried them in a bra yet, just stuck them in my tight tank top, but my sides are still so sore I'm not interested in putting a bra on right now. Any suggestions for things I could wear to the conference just flat-chested?  If I didn't have this little tummy pooch I could just claim the super lean athlete angle..but alas, I have it ;) Any suggestions would be welcomed.  I don't have much extra money but my mom offered to buy me one outfit to wear. Thanks! Dx 4/20/2009, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/1 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Bilateral mx and professional conference MI_Runner Lovegolf

Posts.Content: May 19, 2009 12:59PM MI_Runner wrote: That does help, Lovegolf.  I'll probably only know maybe 30 of 4,500 people at this thing, so really no one will know what I used to look like.  I'm a week post-op now and really still don't want to put a bra on.  I'm not in pain, but my skin feels so sensitive to anything touching it, so I'm wearing really soft camis under everything.  I don't expect to feel differently about that next week, so I'll try the tips posted here.

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2009 08:45PM MI_Runner wrote: Hi Naomi,  I've been feeling very much the same way you described.  Everytime I tell someone else I feel like I hit them over the head with a bat, and most of the time I feel almost detached from it myself.  I think it just hasn't sunk in yet.  The waiting is really very hard, and I too am afraid of losing my hair. I've also had a biopsy of the lump and don't know the stage yet.  They said it's at least stage I because of its size and location, but could go up in stage based on whether any lymph nodes are involved.  Does that sound similar to something your doctor might have said? Good luck with everything. Em
